title: Senolytics To Alleviate Mobility Issues and Neurological Impairment in Aging
description_brief: The purpose of this pilot study is to demonstrate the safety and feasibility of administering intermittent doses of Dasatinib and Quercetin (D+Q) in older adults at risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD). The study will evaluate whether giving D+Q may improve cerebral blood flow regulation, mobility, and cognition in older adults, and thus may prevent progression to Alzheimer's disease.
description_detailed:
The investigators will conduct a 12-week single arm, open label, pre-post pilot study in 12 adults aged 65 or older with slow gait speed (\<1.0 m/sec) and Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI, defined as a Telephone Montreal Cognitive Assessment Score (MoCA) \<19). Participants will be asked to take 100mg of Dasatinib and 1,250mg of Quercetin for 2 consecutive days, every two weeks over a period of 12 weeks (12 doses in total, given over 6 cycles).

At baseline, enrolled participants will undergo gait speed and neurocognitive testing, and provide blood and urine to evaluate biomarkers of senescence. At visits 3,4, 6, and 7, participants will have safety labs drawn, and the study team will assess medication adherence and adverse events. At visits 2, 5, and 8, participants will undergo cognitive assessments, gait speed testing, cerebral blood flow and neurovascular coupling testing. At the final study visit, participants will again provide blood and urine to assess biomarkers of senescence.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: Of the 332 individuals that expressed interest in the study, 115 were screened via telephone. Sixty were ineligible due to not meeting the pre-specified inclusion/exclusion criteria. Of the 55 eligible telephone screeners, 24 were not enrolled due to loss of interest (n=12), loss to follow-up (n=10), or closed enrolment (n=2). Of the 31 participants that were screened in-person, 16 were excluded for various reasons, while 15 individuals were eligible and willing to participate.
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: This study was conducted from 2022-2024 in the greater Boston, MA area. Individuals were recruited through a recruitment firm that utilizes online targeted advertisements based on an individual's browsing history, as well as senior housing presentations, study flyers at clinical practices, and invitations to previous research volunteers who agreed to be in our participant registries.

measures.description: Range: 0-22 points with higher scores indicating higher cognitive status

outcomeMeasures.title: Neurovascular Coupling
outcomeMeasures.description: Change in cerebral blood flow during an N-back cognitive task using transcranial doppler ultrasound.

outcomeMeasures.description: Assess change in executive cognitive function using TRAILS test, corrected for response time. Higher scores indicate worse executive functioning.

outcomeMeasures.title: Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) Score
outcomeMeasures.description: The Montreal Cognitive Assessment evaluates global cognition. Scores range from 0-30 points, with higher scores indicating better cognition

groups.title: Arm 1
groups.description:
Dasatinib and Quercetin

Dasatinib: Dasatinib 100 mg for 2 consecutive days, every two weeks for 12 weeks

Quercetin: Quercetin 1,250 mg for 2 consecutive days, every two weeks for 12 weeks

outcomeMeasures.title: Physical Performance
outcomeMeasures.description: Assessment of overall physical function using the short physical performance battery (SPPB) scored from 0-12, based on a composite of balance, strength, and walking speed. Higher scores indicate better mobility.

outcomeMeasures.title: Mobility
outcomeMeasures.description: Test of mobility using timed up and go test, including standing from a chair, walking, and turning.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: For all participants, adverse events were collected during the entire 14 week study. We were collecting during the period of June 2022 to January 2024, which is approximately 1 year and 8 months.

eventGroups.title: Dasatinib and Quercetin
eventGroups.description: Participants took 100 mg of Dasatinib and 1,250 mg of Quercetin for 2 consecutive days, every two weeks for 12 weeks

seriousEvents.notes: Participant was bitten by family dog on both hands. Waited until next day to go to urgent care which told him to go to hospital emergency room. He was admitted one night (discharged November 12) and sent home with antibiotics.

limitationsAndCaveats.description: Although we collected urine samples, the SASP factors (i.e., biomarkers) we were not measured due to insufficient funds and resources. Therefore, we are unable to analyze any data.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is the combination of dasatinib + quercetin (D+Q), which are small‑molecule senolytic agents intended to remove senescent cells and reduce senescence-associated inflammation with the goal of improving cerebral blood flow, mobility and cognition (i.e., to prevent or slow progression to Alzheimer’s disease). This mechanistic aim is disease‑targeted (senescence biology) rather than symptomatic-only. citeturn0search9turn0search6

Act: Key extracted details from the trial description — Title: "Senolytics To Alleviate Mobility Issues and Neurological Impairment in Aging"; Intervention: Dasatinib (100 mg) + Quercetin (1250 mg) given intermittently (two consecutive days every two weeks for 12 weeks in the STAMINA pilot). The study objective: assess safety/feasibility and whether D+Q may improve cerebral blood flow regulation, mobility, and cognition in older adults at risk for AD. citeturn1search3turn1search0

Reflect: Classification rationale — both dasatinib and quercetin are small molecules (dasatinib is a tyrosine‑kinase inhibitor; quercetin is a flavonoid) and the combination is used as a senolytic to target a disease mechanism (cellular senescence/SASP) that is hypothesized to contribute to AD and age‑related functional decline. Therefore the trial fits the "disease-targeted small molecule" category (not a biologic, not merely a cognitive enhancer or a neuropsychiatric symptomatic treatment). No placebo arm is indicated in the pilot (single‑arm, open‑label pre/post design). citeturn0search9turn0search6turn1search5

Web search results used (summary of sources consulted): 1) ClinicalTrials (NCT05422885) — trial record titled "Senolytics To Alleviate Mobility Issues and Neurological Impairment in Aging" with the same purpose/description. citeturn1search3 2) eBioMedicine / Lancet Family article — pilot (STAMINA) study report describing intermittent D+Q dosing, feasibility, safety and preliminary cognitive/mobility endpoints. citeturn1search0 3) PMC/PubMed basic science paper showing D+Q act as senolytics and reduce SASP/inflammation in aged tissues. citeturn0search9 4) Reviews and preclinical literature on D+Q as senolytics and mechanisms (quercetin flavonoid; dasatinib TKI) supporting the disease‑targeted mechanism. citeturn0search6turn0search2
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is the senolytic drug combination dasatinib + quercetin (D+Q), whose intended biological action is selective elimination of senescent cells by inducing apoptosis or otherwise promoting death of those cells; this is a disease-targeted approach (targeting cellular senescence) rather than a purely symptomatic treatment. Key mechanistic descriptions of D+Q emphasize apoptotic/senolytic activity and downstream reduction of the senescence‑associated secretory phenotype (SASP). citeturn1search0turn1search6

Act: Extracted trial details — Intervention: Dasatinib (100 mg) + Quercetin (1250 mg) given intermittently (2 consecutive days every 2 weeks for 12 weeks) in the STAMINA pilot (NCT05422885). Study purpose: assess safety/feasibility and whether D+Q may improve cerebral blood flow regulation, mobility, and cognition in older adults at risk for AD. These trial design and dosing details are described in the STAMINA rationale/design and the published pilot report. citeturn2search0turn2search9

Reflect: Classification rationale — because the proximate pharmacologic mechanism of the intervention is to induce death/clearance of senescent cells (senolysis), the most specific CADRO match is H) Cell Death. It is correct to note that removing senescent cells also reduces SASP-driven inflammation (an inflammatory effect), so F) Inflammation could be a secondary classification, but the primary, direct target is killing/clearance of senescent cells (cell‑death/senolytic mechanism), so H) Cell Death is the best fit. Supporting sources: mechanistic reviews and preclinical/clinical reports describing D+Q as senolytics that induce apoptosis and reduce SASP. citeturn1search6turn1search0

• STAMINA trial rationale & design (Translational Medicine of Aging) — trial design and dosing for 'Senolytics To Alleviate Mobility Issues and Neurological Impairment in Aging' (NCT05422885). citeturn2search0

• eBioMedicine / Lancet Family pilot report: 'A pilot study of senolytics to improve cognition and mobility in older adults at risk for Alzheimer’s disease' — STAMINA pilot results and methods (D+Q 100 mg + 1250 mg intermittent dosing). citeturn2search2turn2search9

• ALZforum summary describing D+Q as senolytics and noting dasatinib induces apoptosis in senescent cells while quercetin targets anti‑apoptotic factors (Bcl‑xL) and the combination promotes senescent cell death. citeturn1search0
• Review/overview of senolytics (senotherapeutics) summarizing mechanisms of D+Q, apoptosis induction, and SASP reduction. citeturn1search6
